body:
Hey @alangpierce! We really appreciate you taking the time to report an issue. The collaborators
on this project attempt to help as many people as possible, but we're a limited number of volunteers,
so it's possible this won't be addressed swiftly.

If you need any help, or just have general Babel or JavaScript questions, we have a vibrant Slack
community that typically always has someone willing to help. You can sign-up [here](https://slack.babeljs.io/)
for an invite.

That... shouldn't work, `export default` is a value; `interface` is not a value. It's not allowed by typescript's own spec either:

https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/blob/v2.6.2/doc/spec.md#11342-export-default-declarations

This is either a bug in typescript or on its spec.

As a "workaround", you can do `export { A as default }; interface A {}`, which is allowed by the spec.

It was explicitly added in https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/16040 and is part of a list of new `export default` syntaxes that are in progress: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/3792#issuecomment-303526468 , so my guess is the spec hasn't been updated.

I personally would prefer if they didn't do that and kept `export default` strictly with its value semantics... it's already confusing enough to people without having typescript-specific non-value meanings, but rolling it back would be a breaking change... ðŸ˜¢

@Kovensky It's implied by the fact that Typescript shares the same export namespace between types and values. It occasionally causes issues (in particular importing only types from a module with side-effects: what *should* it do?), but most of the time it's simple to pick up what's happening. Except when you can't do a thing with a type that you can with values, like here, where it is just confusing.

@Kovensky, @alangpierce Yeah, the spec is old, hasn't been touched since TS 1.8, with some touchup on 2016-01-20. See [all the open Spec issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/labels/Spec) - it looks like there's now some movement there, but this isn't mentioned.

It's just that `export default` specifically implies an evaluation of its right side, while other `export` forms don't.

But I guess TS can just say that `interface` are a `HoistableDeclaration`.

Exactly, `export default` implies an expression _except_ on the specific exceptions added for `HoistableDeclaration` and `ClassDeclaration`. Those exceptions just makes it so that those specific things that would have looked like assignment expressions (`FunctionExpression` / `ClassExpression`) are considered declarations instead.

An `interface` is not a value nor looks like a valid assignment expression so I don't see it working with `export default`, unless you could argue that it is a `HoistableDeclaration`. `export default type X = Y` is definitely out because that'd be a `VariableDeclaration`, which is not acceptable.

You would also need to make an allowance for `export default interface {}`, to be fully consistent.

It does turn out that `export default (expression that evaluates to a type)` also works too so things are already crazy ðŸ˜–

> those specific things that would have looked like assignment expressions

Not sure what this means? That `export default function foo() {}` should not be interpreted as `const _new_name = function foo() {}, export { _new_name as default }`? That's the same issue as for non-default export declarations, which TS already established a symmetry with type declarations `export interface foo {}`.

If it helps, here's a table:

JS | TS
---|---
`export const x = 123` | `export type T = number`
`export { x }` | `export { T }`
`export class Foo {}` | `export interface Foo {}`
`export default class Foo {}` | `export default interface Foo {}` *new*


> export default type X = Y is definitely out because that'd be a VariableDeclaration, which is not acceptable.

Actually, `export default var x = y` was banned [because it could have multiple bindings](https://esdiscuss.org/topic/why-is-export-default-var-a-1-invalid-syntax), which isn't a problem with `export default type T = U`, so that's actually going in too.

Exactly: `export default function foo () {}` is _not_ the same as `const _default = function foo () {}; export { _default as default }`.

`export default` only allows `AssignmentExpression` (i.e. expressions that have a value that can be assigned to an lvalue). The `HoistableDeclaration` and `ClassDeclaration` exceptions exist to avoid turning those into expressions and keep their declaration nature.

`export default function foo () {}` is the same as `export { foo as default }; function foo () {}`. `export default function () {}` is also valid, and exports a hoisted function whose `name` is `*default*` (with the asterisks).

It's very important that it remains treated as a hoisted function so the behavior is still correct on circular dependencies, even if by not giving it a local name you cannot refer to it inside the module.

I was asking if that was what you were referring to, not it's implications - I had already spec-ed that case's behavior above as export form 4 ðŸ™‚

Your second paragraph seems weird: you say `export default` only allows expressions, then that it has declaration exceptions to preserve the declaration semantics? This is strange logic, expressions and declarations behave completely differently! It is slightly unfortunate that `function foo() {}` and `class Foo {}` are either expressions or declarations (with the resultant differences in semantics) depending on location, but it's hardly the worst language ambiguity in JS.

Surely it's clearer to say "export default allows either expressions or (some) declarations"? Where the excluded declarations in JS are, to my knowledge, only `var`/`let`/`const`, which are excluded because they can introduce multiple names, and it's not worth introducing another form just for export default. That is, it has two syntactic and semantic forms, which I've labeled 3 and 4 above.

By this interpretation, Typescript already had a type equivalent to forms 1 and 2, (forms 5 and 6) and they are adding the missing type equivalent to form 4, form 8.

In other words, I'm claiming that JS specs `Hoistable` and `ClassDeclaration` essentially as "all declarations except variables, cause we don't care about fixing it for `export default var a, b`", so when typescript adds a bunch of other declarations they naturally should be included.

(Incidentally, I'm not sure about `export default function () {}` - `function () {}` is an expression and not a declaration, clearly, and it behaves essentially the same in form 3 barring the function name. It could simply be getting that as a side-effect of transpilation, but if it's explicitly spec-ed as exporting a function named `default`, then you could simply treat it as another special syntax form and semantics for export default if it bothers you)

Sorry if I'm getting repetitive!

`export default` _only_ allows AssignmentExpressions (rvalue expressions) except for things that fall under the lookahead `[lookahead âˆ‰ { function, async [no LineTerminator here] function, class }]`, which is there specifically to allow `export default HoistableDeclaration` and `export default ClassDeclaration` to match unambiguously. https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/#prod-ExportDeclaration

It's only `export` that allows arbitrary `Declaration`s (and `VariableStatement`).

This is by far what people confuse the most about `export default`, because `export default` is very special. `export default` is not an export named default, `export default` is not the default export, `export default` is an expression evaluation that is assigned to a concrete value named `*default*`, and it is _that_ value that is exported as the export named `default`. It has two specific exceptions used to keep `function` and `class` behaving as declarations, instead of being treated as expressions. But `export default` _is a concrete value_.

`export default` is also the only exporter that has non-trivial runtime semantics (except for the `HoistableDeclaration` case).

And `Declaration` is `HoistableDeclaration` or `ClassDeclaration` or `LexicalDeclaration`; that is "`HoistableDeclaration` or `ClassDeclaration`" is identical to "`Declaration` - `LexicalDeclaration`". The way in which the grammar is specified in the spec is so that it is unambiguous, and BNF languages don't generally provide features like "try A, otherwise try B", or "C, unless it's a D". Don't take the specific form of the grammar as a statement from TC39 that they only like functions and classes!

Your third statement reads just flat out wrong: `export default` is absolutely syntax for an export named `default`. See the equivalences above, 2 and 4 are identical except for the exported binding name being renamed to `default`, and precluding variables for syntactic reasons, and 3 is just 4 with an implicit variable being rebound as `default`. If you support `export { foo as bar }` correctly, you can implement all the others in terms of it. On the import side, `import foo from ...` is identical to `import { default as foo } from ...`.

If it helps: try "there is no `export <Expression>;` form, because what's it's name?", then maybe it's clearer that exporting declarations is the default (no pun intended), and it's `export default <Expression>` that's a special case (in that it creates a value without introducing a local name).

In any case, it's a *fait accompli*, [and more are coming](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/18628), so I guess... get used to it?
run in the same issue after switch from at-loader to babel.

issue.title: [plugin-transform-typescript] Default or named exported interface result in runtime error

issue.title: Typescript - Unexpected token, expected ";"

repository.name: babel
repository.description: ðŸ  Babel is a compiler for writing next generation JavaScript.

issue.body:
## Bug Report

**Current Behavior**
Failing to compile correct code

**Input Code**
- REPL or Repo link if applicable:

```ts
import {NetworkListenerEvent} from "../listeners/network-listener";

export enum NetworkControllerEnvironment {
    Unicast,
    Multicast,
    Broadcast,
    All
}

export default interface NetworkController {
    readonly endpoint: string;
    readonly environment: NetworkControllerEnvironment;
    readonly handle: (event: NetworkListenerEvent) => void;
}
```

**Expected behavior/code**
Compile successfully

**Babel Configuration (.babelrc, package.json, cli command)**

```js
{
    "presets": [
        "@babel/env",
        "@babel/typescript"
    ],
    "plugins": [
        "@babel/proposal-class-properties",
        "@babel/proposal-object-rest-spread"
    ]
}
```

**Environment**
- Babel version(s): v7.0.0-beta.49
- Node/npm version: 5.6.0
- OS: Windows 10
- Monorepo: no
- How you are using Babel: cli

**Possible Solution**
<!--- Only if you have suggestions on a fix for the bug -->

**Additional context/Screenshots**
Stack trace:
```
$ tsc --emitDeclarationOnly && babel src --out-dir lib --extensions ".ts,.tsx"
{ SyntaxError: D:\Projects\local-network\src\core\network-controller.ts: Unexpected token, expected ";" (10:25)

   8 | }
   9 |
> 10 | export default interface NetworkController {
     |                          ^
  11 |     readonly endpoint: string;
  12 |     readonly environment: NetworkControllerEnvironment;
  13 |     readonly handle: (event: NetworkListenerEvent) => void;
    at _class.raise (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:3861:15)
    at _class.unexpected (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:5190:16)
    at _class.semicolon (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:5174:40)
    at _class.parseExportDefaultExpression (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:8149:12
)
    at _class.parseExportDefaultExpression (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:9801:65
)
    at _class.parseExport (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:8102:31)
    at _class.parseExport (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:9784:50)
    at _class.parseStatementContent (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:7172:27)
    at _class.parseStatementContent (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:9816:58)
    at _class.parseStatement (D:\Projects\local-network\node_modules\@babel\parser\lib\index.js:7085:17)
  pos: 200,
  loc: Position { line: 10, column: 25 },
  code: 'BABEL_PARSE_ERROR' }
```

body: @Kovensky How would it sound to you to have this parse, but have the TS transform throw an exception saying it is unsupported in Babel? It seems like we should support it in the parser at least, since plenty of tooling would want to use it for static analysis, even if they don't use it for transformation.

That would be weird. The TS transform otherwise is tracking new typescript features, the only transform exceptions are ones that require whole-program transformation (`const enum`, `namespace` [though I'm not convinced by that one (but thats a different story!)]). Like all pure-type decls, the transform is just to delete it.

Why would @Kovensky get to veto typescript language features just because he doesn't like them?
